fields: Which drugs can cause malignant hyperthermia?

Succinylcholine/suxamethonium
Volatile inhaled anesthetics/old halogenated anaesthetics (Halothane)

Which anaesthetics are preferred for induction of anaesthesia and why

{{c1::IV, as they tend to be rapid in action and rapidly excreted}}
Only BDZs anaesthetics eg midazolam have longer DoAs
The only IV anaesthetic used in mngmt is {{c1::propofol}} because it is {{c2::rapidly eliminated::process}}
IV generally not used in mngmt coz they have slow metabolism, hence anaesthesia can 'carry over'

Why do IV anaesthetics distribute into the CNS(chemical properties)

{{c1::Lipophilic, non-ionized}}

What accounts for termination of the effect of single IV bolus of anaesthetics?

{{c1::Redistribution of the anaesthetic to less perfused tissues eg skeletal muscle}}

Why do IV anaesthetics have similar DoA despite different metabolisms

{{c1::Becuase of the redistribution that all IV drugs undergo, to other peripheral tissues}}

When does redistribution of IV drugs to adipose become important

{{c1::After repeated admins, where it can become a reservoir, thus leading to prolonged effects}}
Adipose tissue receives poor perfusion thus doesn't get the redistributed drug initially, only after repeated admins(check green dotted curve ↓)

What changes are made to an IV anaesthetic dose when smn has shock(ie speed and dose) and why

{{c1::
  1. Slow titration of a reduced dose
  2. In shock(↓ CO), blood is diverted centrally, meaning more of IV drug will reach brain
    1. Also, circulation is slower }}

Give 2 alkyl phenol IV anaesthetics

{{c1::
  1. Propofol
  2. Fospropofol
}}

Differentiate propofol and fospropofol(2)

{{c1::
  1. Fos is the prodrug of propofol
  2. Fos is water soluble(hence isn't used in the oil-H2O emulsion)
    1. Thus also causes less injection pain
}}

What are the drawbacks of the oil-water emulsion that propofol is admined as(3)

{{c1::
  1. May cause transient pain on injection
  2. Supports microbial growth(but retardants of bact growth used)
  3. May cause allergic rxns(has soybean oil, glycerol, lecithin)
 }}

1. [[oc1::Poorly H2O soluble]]
    1. [[oc1::Thus admined as oil-water emulsion]]
  2. [[oc2::Rapid OoA(30-40s) and redistribution to peripheral tissues(2-4 min)]]
  3. [[oc3::Has 1st order kinetics met in liver]]
  4. [[oc4::Excreted in kidney(about 70%)]]
  5. [[oc5::Pulmonary clearance accounts for 30% of excretion]]

After taking induction doses of propofol, ptns usually wake up after {{c1::8-10 mins::duration}}

Which chemical used with propofol has brought doubts to its use in reactive airway dx

{{c1::Metabisulfite}}

Differentiate thiopental and propofol in terms of 
  1. Metabolism
  2. Hangover effects(and reason why)

{{c1::
  1. Propofol has 1st order met in liver(while thiopental has saturation kinetics)
  2. Propofol produces less hangover coz of high plasma clearance(compared to accumulation in fat of thiopental)
}}

Give the CNS effects of propofol(3)

{{c1::
  1. General suppression of CNS
  2. has NO analgesic activity
  3. ↓ cerebral BF⇒↓ in intraocular and ICP
}}

Give the effects of propofol on CVS(specific, 2)

{{c1::
  1. Hypotension
  2. Bradycardia
}}

Why is propofol preferred to thiopental for instrumentation of upper airway

{{c1::It produces stronger inhibition of upper airway reflexes eg cough and gag reflex}}
Effect of propofol on respiratory system is {{c1::depression}}

In which cases does propofol infusion syndrome occur

{{c1::When it has been infused for a long time to maintain sedation- esp in sick patients- esp in children}}
Occurs in 1:300 ptns of propofol

Symptoms of propofol infusion syndrome(8)

{{c1::
  1. Hyperkalemia
  2. Lipemia
  3. Arrhythmias
  4. Rhambomyolisis
  5. Hepatomegaly
  6. Metabolic acidosis
  7. CV collapse
  8. Renal failure}}

Effect of propofol on area postrema?

{{c1::Inhibition ie is anti-emetic}}

How do you reduce pain associated with propofol injection(4)

{{c1::
  1. Opioid premedication
  2. Co-admin lidocaine
  3. Dilute propofol
  4. Use larger veins
}}

1. [[oc1::GA induction(DoC)]]
  2. [[oc2::Maintenance of anaesthesia]]
  3. [[oc3::Esp useful in day-case surgery]]
  4. Others
    1. [[oc4::Sedation of ventilated ptns in ICU]]
    2. [[oc4::Conscious sedation during procedures]]
    3. [[oc4::Short-duration GA outside operating room]]
    4. [[oc5::Postop NV treatment(subanaesthetic doses)]]

Used in maintenance because it rapidly metabolized

MoA of propofol?

{{c1::As most others, potentiates GABA effects at GABAa receptors}}
The only IV anaesthetic that doesn't explicitly potentiate GABAa effects is ketamine, which activates NMDA receptors

Which 2 barbiturates are the only ones still used as anaesthetics

{{c1::
Thiopental
Methohexital}}

MoA of barbiturates as anaesthetics?

{{c1::
  1. MAIN - potentiation of GABA effects(GABAa)
  2. Inhibition of glutamate effects
}}
They score both ways

Give the effects of barbiturates on CVS(brain) and resp

{{c1::
  1. CVS - ↓ ICP
  2. Resp - resp inhibition(cough, bronchospasm, chest pain)
}}

What is the effect of barbiturates in the liver and thus in which group is it contraindicated

{{c1::
  1. It induces liver enzymes(esp haem eznymes)
  2. Thus contraindicated in porphyria ptns as it can precipitate attacks
}}

1. [[oc1::Free acid insoluble in water]]
    1. [[oc1::Hence given as Na salt]]
  2. [[oc2::85% albumin bound]]
  3. [[oc3::High lipid solubility]]
    1. [[oc3::Hence quick onset(20s) and effect lasts 5-10 mins]]
  4. [[oc4::Shows saturation kinetics(contrast with propofol)]]
  5. [[oc5::Accumulates in adipose tissue]]

Why does thiopental produce effects long after surgery/admin

{{c1::It accumulates in body fat and is metabolized slowly}}

AEs of thiopental(2)

{{c1::
  1. Due to alkalinity + injection
    1. Pain
    2. Necrosis and ulceration
    3. Arterial spasm
    4. Gangrene eventually
  2. Drowsiness and resp depression(due to slow met and release from fat)
}}

Uses of barbiturates(thiopental and methohexital)in anaesthesia(4)

{{c1::'
  1. Induction of GA
  2. Short surgical procedures
  3. Termination of status epilepticus
  4. ↓ ICP in ptns with secure airway
}}

Are barbiturates(thiopental) admined with analgesics and why

{{c1::Yes}}
Have low analgesic effect

is propofol admined with analgesics

{{c1::Yes}}
Has no analgesic effect

Give 3 benzodiazepines used as anaesthetic agents

{{c1::
  1. Midazolam(main)
  2. Diazepam
  3. Lorazepam
}}

MoA of benzodiazepines

{{c1::Enhance inhibitory NT(GABA)}}
As it turns out, they ARE IV anaesthetics(which predominantly do the same thing)

Effect of benzodiazepines on CVS/resp

{{c1::
  1. Minimal CVS effects
  2. Resp depression
}}
{{c1::Erythromycin::antibiotic}} may prolong effects of benzodiazepines
Is a CYP inhibitor

AE associated with benzodiazepine use in anaesthesia

{{c1::Anterograde amnesia(temporary)}}
Is where there is only partial loss of consciousness with amnesia and analgesia

Compare speed of action of etomidate and thiopental and the effect of that

{{c1::It is rapidly metabolized, hence ↓ likely to cause hangover effects}}

AEs of etomidate?(3)

{{c1::
  1. Suppression of adrenal steroid prod
  2. Postop NV
  3. Injection site RX and involuntary skeletal muscle mvmts
}}

Which IV anaesthetic is used in ptns with CAD/circulatory failure ptns and why

{{c1::Etomidate. It lacks cardiodepressant activity}}

When is etomidate cautioned

{{c1::Ptns with adrenal insufficiency}}
{{c2::Ketamine::IV anaesthetic}} resembles {{c1::phencyclidine}} structurally
Ketamine has a {{c1::slower::speed}} onset of action than thiopental
1-2 mins compared to 20s in thiopental

Ketamine MoA

{{c1::Inhibition of NMDA receptors}}
It together with xenon and NO are the only ones to do so

Differences in effects of ketamine and phencyclidine

{{c1::Ketamine produces less euphoria and sensory distortion}}

Give effects of ketamine in SNS, resp and cerebral BF

{{c1::
  1. ↑ sympathetic outflow(↑ BP)
  2. Bronchodilator(or doesn't cause respiratory depression)
  3. ↑ cerebral BF
}}

Give 2 'atypical' uses of ketamine

{{c1::
  1. Analgesic at lower doses
  2. Acute treatment of depression
}}
Ketamine is C/Id in {{c1::hypertensive}} ptns
It can worsen because it ↑ SNS activity

Dexmedetomidine receptor action

{{c1::alpha-2 agonist in certain areas of the brain}}

Give the inhalational anaesthetics that were discontinued coz of explosive potential(3)

{{c1::
  1. Cyclopropane
  2. Ethylene
  3. Ethyl chloride
}}

Volatile liquid inhalational anaesthetics

{{c1::
  1. Halothane
  2. All ending with -flurane(methoxyflurane, enflurane, isoflurane, desflurane, sevoflurane)
}}
The value of therapeutic index of inhaled anaesthetics ranges from {{c1::2-4}}
↓ safety margins

Define partition coefficient as pertains to inhalational anaesthetics

{{c1::The ratio of concentrations of a drug in different media when the partial pressure in the 2 media is equal}}
Thus, ↓ partition coefficient means a drug has ↓ solubility in that medium
{{c1::Dantrolene}} is used to treat {{c2::malignant hyperthermia}}
Malignant hyperthermia is a major idiosyncratic AE of inhaled anaesthetics, mostly of the old halogenated ones(ie not sevoflurane and desflurane)

Give the 4 major factors determining speed of induction and recovery of inhalational anaesthetics

{{c1::
  1. Anaesthetics factors
    1. Blood:gas partition coefficient(inverse)
    2. Oil:gas partition coefficient
  2. Physiological factors
    1. Alveolar ventilation rate
    2. CO
}}
Inhaled anaesthetics are mainly used for {{c1::maintenance::induction/maintenance}} of GA
IVs mainly used for induction coz they are more rapidly metabolized
Potency of an anaesthetic and MAC are {{c1::inversely::directly/inversely}} related
e.g. N2O with 105 MAC has ↓ potency; halothane with 0.75 MAC has ↑ potency

The type of drug interaction seen with inhalational agents?(2)

{{c1::
  • Additive 
  • Synergistic
}}
Give the 4 special effects that ketamine has on body

1. Dissociative amnesia - where all features of anaesthesia are there except loss of consciousness
  2. ↑ ICP(only IV anaesthetic to do so)
  3. ↑ CVS activity(hence C/Id in hypertensives)
    1. Has no resp effect/bronchodilation
  4. May caause hallucinations, delirium post op
Give the effects propofol has on CNS, CVS, resp, area postrema

1. CNS
    1. General suppression
    2. ↓ in ICP(all but ketamine do so)
    3. NO analgesic effect(hence combined with analgesics(
  2. CVS and resp - depression
  3. Area postrema - anti-emetic
Which IV anaesthetic is likely to cause hangover effects
Thiopental
Give 2 important coefficients in anaesthetics and their relevance

1. Blood:gas coefficient - determines speed of induction and recovery
  2. Fat:gas coefficient - determines potency
What is the relevance of fat solubility in inhalational anaesthetics
More fat soluble anaesthetics will have slower recovery and more 'hangover' effects eg halothane

Give the effects of enflurane on resp

{{c1::
  1. ↓ in saliva and tracheal secretions
  2. ↓ in laryngeal and pharynx reflexes
  3. general resp suppression
  4. bronchodilation
}}

These are taken to be the prototypical effects unless stated otherwise
  1. ​RESP
    1. ↓ in saliva and tracheal secretions
    2. ↓ in laryngeal and pharynx reflexes
    3. general resp suppression
    4. bronchodilation
CNS
  1. ↑ in convulsions
  2. ↑ O2 consumption
  3. ↑ in CBF(headaches, ↑ ICP)​
MSK
  1. Malignant hyperthermia
  2. Muscle relaxation(even uterine)​
CVS - vasodilation(hypotension)​
​↓ in eye and pupil constriction↓ renal and hepatic BF​​​

{{c1::It together with desflurane ↑ HR and BP when MAC is high enough}}

  1. ​RESP
    1. ↓ in saliva and tracheal secretions

Give 3 special PD aspects of sevoflurane

{{c1::
  1. Prolongs QT interval
  2. Maintains hepatic BF(↓ portal vein BUT ↑ hepatic artery flow)
  3. Renotoxic(due to fluoride)
}}

  2. Muscle relaxation(even uterine)​
CVS - vasodilation(hypotension)​
​↓ in eye and pupil constriction↓ renal and hepatic BF​​​

  1. Shared with ether
    1. ↑ in HR and BP
    2. NV
  2. ↑ RR
  3. ↓ hepatic bf LESS that others

Which is the most soluble inhalational anaesthetics in fat and its effect

{{c1::Halothane. Its the one most associated with slow recovery}}

Give 4 AEs of halothane

{{c1::
  1. Hypotension
  2. Bradycardia
  3. Malignant hyperthermia
  4. Hepatotoxicity(due to met to trfluoroacetate}}

Give 2 CIs of isoflurane

{{c1::
  1. Hypovolemics
  2. People with existing MI(is the most potent vasodilator; ↑ ischemia due to steal phenomenon)}}

Give 5 CIs of N2O and the reason for it

{{c1::
  1. It accumulates in gaseous cavities hence CId in
    1. Pneumocephalus
    2. Air embolism
    3. Tympanic memb graft
    4. Pneumothorax
    5. Intestine obstruction
}}

Give 2 inhalational anaesthetics metabolized to fluorides and their effects

{{c1::
  1. Halothane - may be hepatotoxic
  2. Sevoflurane - renotoxic}}

Which inhalational anaesthetic is the most potent coronary vasodilator and the effect

{{c1::Isoflurane. It may exacerbate MI due to steal phenomenon}}

Give 4 inhalational anaesthetics that ↑ HR and BP

{{c1::
  1. Constitutively
    1. NO
    2. Ether
  2. At certain MACs
    1. Isoflurane
    2. Desflurane
}}

Which is the most proconvulsant inhaled anaesthetic

{{c1::enflurane}}

Which 2 anaesthetics are nephrotoxic

{{c1::Sevoflurane. Methoxyflurane}}

Give 5 groups of local anaesthetic(LA) classifications

{{c1::
  1. Ester LA
  2. Amide LA
  3. Ethers
  4. Ketones
  5. Phenetidin derivatives
}}

Match the following with their LA class

{{c2::Ethers}} - {{c3::pramoxine}}
{{c2::Ketones}} - {{c4::dyclonine}}
{{c3::Phenetidin derivative}} - {{c4::phenacaine}}

Give 5 examples of ester LA

{{c5::
  1. Cocaine
  2. Procaine
  3. Chlorprocaine
  4. Benzocaine
  5. Tetracaine
  6. Cinchocaine/dibucaine
}}

Give examples(6) of amide LA(mnemonic {{c7::BELAMP}})

{{c6::
  1. Bupivacaine
  2. Etidocaine
  3. Lidocaine/lignocaine
  4. Articaine
  5. Mepivacaine
  6. Prilocaine
}}

Give the pH properties of local anaesthetics

{{c1::Weak bases}}

• Pka of about 8-9
  • Important coz
    1. Their activity increases in alkaline pH(due to ↓ ionization)
    2. Are marketed as salts, which ↑ their solubility

Why are local anaesthetics ineffective in inflamed tissues

{{c2::Inflamed tissues are relatively acidic, thus LAs are in ionized form and can't cross memb to act on neurons}}

MoA of LAs

{{c3::Block voltage gated Na+ channels from within neuron}}
Show use-dependence

Give the factors that determine the effectiveness of a local anaesthetic

{{c4::
  1. Frequency of stimulation of that nerve(↑ with ↑ frequency), ie use dependence
  2. Size of nerve fibre
  3. pKa and pH
  4. Lipid solubility
  5. Molecular size
}}

What effects does one get after admining LA and vasopressors eg epinephrine/phenylephrine(2)

{{c1::
  1. Localization of the LA to the area
  2. ↓ of systemic AEs of LA(because of ↓ sysytemic circulation)
}}
BUT epinephrine in skeletal muscle causes vaso<font color="#ffff00">dilation</font> so produces opposite effects

Why are drugs like epinephrine, clonidine or dexmedetomidine used in spinal anaesthesia

{{c2::Are alpha-2 agonists, which ↓ substance P(neurokinin-1) release and ↓ sensory neuron firing}}

Contrast metabolism of amide vs ester LA

{{c1::
  1. Ester LA- metabolized by plasma esterases eg pseudocholinesterase
  2. Amide LA- metabolized by liver enzymes through N-dealkylation then hydrolysis(except prilocaine)
}}

Amide LA​Ester LA​
In liver​In plasma​
N-dealkylation→hydrolysis​Hydrolysis by plasma esterases ​

What is special about prilocaine as an amide LA

{{c2::Metabolized by hydrolysis first, to form O-toluidine}}
Unlike others that are N-dealkylated first

In which tissue/fluid do ester LAs persist the longest and why

{{c3::CSF. It has no esterases to metabolize the ester LA}}

Based on the metabolism of amide LAs, give 3 CIs

{{c4::
  1. People with hepatic impairment
  2. Ppl with ↓ hepatic BF
    1. Including after inhaled GA
}}
Give the order in which sensory modalities are lost after LA admin
pain→temperature→touch→deep pressure→motor function
Give 3 PK aspects of amide LAs and their clinical correlates

55-95% alpha-acid glycoprotein bound​Therefore CId in neonates and oral contraceptive takers(have ↓ levels→can predispose to toxicity​
Met in liver by N-dealkylation(excpet prilocaine partially)​CId in hepatic disease/↓ hepatic BF​
Excreted in urine(and are basic drugs)​acidifying urine can ↑ excretio eg ammonium chloride​
Describe the development of CNS AEs after admin of LAs

1. CNS stimulation effects
    1. Restlessness
    2. Tremor
    3. Maybe even convulsions
  2. CNS depression
    1. Most importantly resp depression, which is the cause of death after LA admin
Which LA is particularly potent in CNS effects and which have been brought to replace it
Procaine and mepivacaine, which have largely been replaced with lido, tetra, prilo, arti, bupiva
Which 2 local anaesthetics cause euphoria

Cocaine and lidocaine

Cocaine by inhibiting catecholamine reuptake transporters
Give the general CVS AEs of local anaesthetics

↓ in CDI ie bradycardia, hypotension. Also vasodilation(except cocaine and bupiva??)

All these can result in cv collapse
Which is the most potent LA in CVS effects and its milder isomer? which drug similar to the former drug produces less CVS effects

Bupivacaine is more potent CVS, while its isomer levobupivacaine produces ↓ CVS effects.
Ropivacaine produces ↓ CVS effects

N/B- recall bupivacaine has the adv over procaine in CNS effects
Which LA produces CVS effects contrary to what is expected and how
Cocaine. It inhibits catecholamine reuptake, which ↑ SNS activity, thus causing tachycardia, hypertension etc
Many smooth muscles are relaxed by LAs. Which are the only not to be relaxed
Uterine
Effect of procaine on NMJ
↓ its response to Ach
Give the AEs of LAs(5)

CNS effects - stimulation then depression
CVS effects - ↓ in CDI except cocaine
Hypersensitivity rxns
Cocaine causes mucosal irritation
Prilocaine causes methemoglobinemia
How is prilocaine metabolized, what is the effect of this and this CI

Unlike other amide LAs, it is first hydroxylated to toluidine, which can cause methemoglobinemia
Thus is CId in pregnancy
Where is procaine, specifically, CId
Is a PABA analog, hence can ↓ effect of sulfonamides. Thus co-admin is not allowed

Sketchy Pharmacology: Neuro/Psych 

Malignant hyperthermia is treated by {{c1::dantrolene}}, which is a {{c2::ryanodine}} receptor antagonist that prevents release of Ca2+ from the SR

First Aid Pharmacology: Neuro/Psych

Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant that is used to treat {{c1::malignant hyperthermia}} and {{c2::neuroleptic malignant syndrome}}

First Aid Pharmacology: Neuro/Psych 

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome may be treated with {{c1::dantrolene}} or a {{c2::D2}} agonist
e.g. bromocriptine

First Aid Pharmacology: Neuro/Psych 

Baclofen exerts its effects by {{c2::activation::activation/inhibition}} of {{c1::GABAB}} receptors at the spinal cord level, causing muscle {{c3::relaxation}}
inhibits glutamate release from the pre-synaptic neuron & also enhances effects of inhibitory interneuron on post-synaptic neuron
{{c1::Botulinum toxin::which exotoxin}} inhibits {{c2::Acetylcholine}} release at the neuromuscular junction, resulting in lack of {{c2::muscle contraction}}
Inhibits exocytosis of Ach
What is the pharmacological treatment for Malignant Hyperthermia?
Dantrolene
What is the mechanism of action of Dantrolene?
Ryanodine receptor antagonist
Patients taking Tizanidine can develop hypotension, weakness, and {{c1::xerostomia::oral complication}}
used for relief of spasticity (CNS muscle relaxant)
Baclofen is an agonist of {{c1::GABAB}} in the spinal cord

which can be found on interneurons, as well as pre-synaptic neurons

→ reduces glutamate's excitation
What is the clinical indication for Baclofen(3)?

Muscle spasticity( of MS and cerebral origin)
Dystonia
Multiple Sclerosis
Baclofen can be used in treatment of which demyelinating disorder?
Multiple Sclerosis
What in plasma is monitored when admining tizanidine
Liver enzyme levels(LFTs). Is even contraindicated in severe hepatic impairment
What may ↓ the effectiveness of botulinum clinically
Immune reaction ie is immunogenic
Generalization of AEs of botulinum toxin

1. Muscle paralysis eg diff swallowing, resp depression etc
  2. Parasympathetic paralysis eg blurred vision, dry mouth etc
  3. May also cause injection site rx
Give uses of botulinum toxin

1. Forehead wrinkles
  2. Muscle
    1. Blepharospasm
    2. Squint
    3. Spasticity
    4. Urinary incontinence
  3. Secretions
    1. Hyperhidrosis
    2. Sialorrhea
  4. Headache prophylaxis
Give the muscle relaxant drugs NOT indicated for anaesthesia(ie for muscle spasms)

Diazepam
Dantrolene
Baclofen
Tizanidine
Botulinum
Differentiate non-depolarising NMJ blockers based on parent molecule

1. Parent molecule
    1. Steroids - curoniums
    2. Isoquinoline derivatives - the rest
Differentiate NMJ blockers based on DoA

1. Long acting
    1. Tubocurarine
    2. Pancuronium
  2. Intermediate acting
    1. Vecuronium
    2. Atracurium
  3. Short acting
    1. Mivacurium
    2. Suxamethonium
MoA of non-depolarising NMJ blockers

1. Competitively inhibit nicotinic receptors
  2. Cause tetanic fade ie progressively ↓ Ach release from repeatedly firing motor neurons
Give the chemical structure of NMJ blocking drugs and PKs(4) in that respect

1. Are quartenary cpds hence
    1. Poor oral abs
    2. Poor distribution(thus very applicable for obstetric anaesthesia as they won't cross placenta)
    3. Met in liver
    4. Excreted in urine well
What exceptions to general PKs of NMJ blockers do atracurium and mivacurium have

Atracurium - spontaneously hydrolysed in plasma(by design)in physiological pH
Mivacurium - hydrolyzed by plasma cholinesterase(also suxamethonium)



Atracurium is stab;e in alkaline pH
Why are the short acting NMJ blockers short acting
Are the only ones metabolized by plasma cholinesterases(ie mivacurium and suxamethonium
Give the DIs of non-depolarising NMJ blockers

1. Cholinesterase inh ↓ action
  2. Aminoglycosides ↑ action by competing with Ca, thus ↓ Ca mediated exocytosis of Ach 
  3. CCBs also ↑ action(like #2)
  4. Hydrogenated hydrocarbon anaesthetics eg halothane ↑ action by stabilizing them at NMJ
Which are the first and last muscles to be blocked by NMJ blockers`
Eye→face→limbs→pharynx→resp muscles(last and brief)
Which drugs are used to reverse NMJ blockers toxicity

Neostigmine+atropine

Atropine to prevent excessive neostigmine action
{{c2::Sugammadex}} is the drug used to reverse {{c1::vecuronium/rocuronium}} toxicity
Forms an inactive complex with them in plasma
Which is the depolarizing NMJ blocking agent? Use? MoA?

Suxamethonium.
Used for tracheal intubation and electroconvulsive shock therapy
Acts by depolarising nicotinic receptors⇒flaccid paralysis
Differentiate the pattern of NMJ block produced by depolarising vs non-depolarising NMJ blockers

Depolarising - cause fasciculations befoe paralysis
Non - cause tetanic fade
Give 6 AEs of suxamethonium with explanation. The AEs dictate the CIs

1. Bradycardia - due to M2 receptor stimulation
  2. Ventricular dysrrhythmias with hyperkalemic states eg burns, trauma(motor denervation)
  3. ↑ intraocular pressure(due to ↑ stimulation of nerves za hapo)
  4. Prolonged paralysis, only in
    1. People with cholinestrerase issues
    2. Neonates(↓ cholinesterase)
    3. Anti-cholinesterase drugs
  5. Malignant hyperthermia in those genetically predisposed
  6. Post-operative myalgia
In addition to the normal NMJ blockade, gve 3 other MoAs of tubocurarine and thei AE implications. Give 2 drugs with a similar profile

Tubocurarine causes
  1. Ganglion blockade - hypotension
  2. Histamine release - hypotension and bronchoconstriction

Atracurium and mivacurium also do the same(only cause transient hypotension)
What effect do pancuronium and gallamine share? Which drug is similar to pancuronium in this respect

They both block M2 receptors → tachycardia and hypertension. 

Pipecuronium is similar to pancuronium
What is the adv and disadv of vecuronium? Which drug is similar to it

Adv - fewer side effects that the long acting
Disadv - may cause prolonged paralysis due to active metabolite
Rocuronium is similar but has a faster onset
Give the derivatives of atracurium and the advs they have over atracurium

Doxacurium - more stable in plasma, hence ↑ DoA
Cisatracurium - >potent with ↓ histamine action(hence ↓ hypotension)
Suxamethonium + vecuronium = {{c1::rocuronium}}
ie rocuronium has few AEs like vecuronium, but fast onset of action like suxamethonium

note_models.name: Cloze-88141
lolnotacop's microbiology
Cloze-Lightyear

fields:
Give the components of the anaesthetic state(4)

{{c1::
  1. Amnesia
  2. Analgesia
    1. Also, loss of autonomic reflexes to noxious stimuli
    2. Immobility to noxius stimuli
  3. Unconsciousness
  4. Skeletal muscle relaxation(loss of reflexes)
}}

What is balanced anaesthesia

{{c1::Involves using combination of drugs to reduce their AEs, while maximizing analgesia and other effects of general anaesthesia}}

Contrast mngmt of short diagnostic procedures vs extensive surgeries

{{c1::
  1. Short diagnostic procedures/minor surgeries
    • Local anaesthetics/sedatives
  2. Extensive surgeries
    • Pre-anaesthetic drugs eg benzodiazepines(sedatives)
    • Induce GA with IV agents
    • Maintain GA intra-surgery with inhaled or IV agents(only propofol)
}}

Which chemical was used to describe the stages of anaesthesia

{{c1::Diethyl ether}}

Which gas is a complete anaesthetic and why?

{{c1::
  1. Ether
  2. It produces all the anaesthetic effects(AAUR) at concentrations that allow suff. oxygenation
}}
AAUR - amnesia, analgesia, unconsciousness, relaxation of smooth muscle/loss of reflexes

Give the 2 general groups of IV anaesthetic adjuncts

{{c1::
  1. Benzodiazepines
    1. Diazepam
    2. Midazolam
    3. Lorazepam
  2. Opioid analgesics
    1. Fentanyl & congeners
    2. Morphine
}}

What is the effect of anaesthetics on GABA receptors

{{c1::Potentiate GABA effects on GABAa receptors(↑ sensitivity) thus enhance inhibition
}}
except cyclopropane, ketamine and xenon

Where do propofol/etomidate exert their sedative/analgesic actions

{{c1::Beta2 subunit of GABAa receptor}}

Which are the only anaesthetics to not activate GABA receptors(4)

{{c1::
  1. Cyclopropane
  2. Nitrous oxide
  3. Ketamine
  4. Xenon
}}
These are the same ones that inhibit NMDA receptors

Which are the only IV anaesthetics to NOT activate {{c2::glycine}} receptors

{{c1::Ketamine}}
{{c1::Etomidate}}

Which anaesthetics inhibit Glu-gated NMDA receptors

{{c1::
  1. Cyclopropane
  2. NO
  3. Xenon
  4. Ketamine
}}
These are the ones that DO NOT inhibit GABA receptors

Which anaesthetics act on 2-pore K channels(4)

{{c1::
  1. Cyclopropane
  2. NO
  3. Xenon
  4. Halogenated GAs}}
Generally, IV anaesthetics do not

Give the receptors that anaesthetics act on

{{c1::
  1. GABAa receptors
    1. Glycine receptors
    2. Ach nicotinic receptors
  2. 2-pore K channels
  3. NMDA receptors(the 4
}}

Which anaesthetic actions are mediated at nicotinic receptors

{{c1::
  1. Analgesia
  2. Amnesia
}}

Match the following effects in anaesthesia with the region of the CNS affected
  1. {{c4::Analgesia & unconsciousness}} - {{c1::midbrain reticular formation & thalamic sensory relay nuclei}}
  2. {{c5::Amnesia}} - {{c2::hippocampus}}
  3. {{c6::Loss of reflexes}} - {{c3::spinal cord}}
Death due to high anaesthetic doses is due to {{c1::respiratory failure}}

What effect on heart do all anaesthetics share

{{c1:: ↓ in cardiac contractility}}

What 2 effects inhaled anaesthetics have on the CVS

{{c1::
  1. ↓ BP ⇐ ↓ sympathetic output and thus ↓ venous and arterial tone
  2. Cause ventricular extrasystoles(extra-beats) }}
#1 except isoflurane, desflurane, NO and ether

What effects do N2O and ketamine have on BP(as anaesthetic agents

{{c1::↑ via ↑ sympathetic discharge }}

Give 3/4 effects of anaesthetics on resp system

{{c1::
  1. Depression on respiratory drive
  2. Loss of reflexes eg
    1. Gag reflex
    2. Cough reflex
  3. LES tone is reduced}}

Which are the only anaesthetics that do not affect resp system(3)

{{c1::
  1. NO
  2. Xenon
  3. Ketamine
}}

Why is desflurane only used in mngmt of anaesthesia rather than induction

{{c1::It is pungent and has potent resp-depression actions hence can cause coughing, laryngospasm and bronchospasm, hence not used}}

Give the effects of anaesthetics on temp(2 leading to 1)

{{c1::
  1. ↓ temp set point in hypothalamus → ↑ vasodilation → ↑ heat loss ⇒ ↓ temp
  2. ↓ met rate of body → ↓ heat gen ⇒ ↓ temp
}}

Which anaesthetic& immunosuppressive agents used post-operatively may have ↓ NV

{{c1::
  1. Ketorolac(???)
  2. Propofol
}}

What effect do anaesthetics have on the area postrema
{{c1::Trigger it ⇒ vomiting}}
except ketorolac and propofol
The main phenomena occuring in emergence(postoperative) are {{c1::hyper}}tension and {{c1::tachy}}cardia
Because for most anaesthetics, they cause bradycardia and hypotension

Give emergence phenomena that occur postop(5) other than hypertension and tachycardia

{{c1::
  1. Excitement(tachycardia, restlessness, crying)
  2. Neurologic signs(delirium, spasticity)
  3. Shivering
  4. Airway obstruction and pulm edema
  5. Hypoxia
}}

How is hypothermia from anaesthetics managed

{{c1::Meperidine}}

How are emergence phenomena prevented intraop(2)

{{c1::
  1. Opioids
  2. Alpha2 agonists
}}

Give the terms used to measure anaesthetic potency and their meanings

{{c1::
  1. Minimum alveolar concentration or its equivalent for IV anaesthetics
  2. MAC means concentration required to prevent movement in response to surgical incisions in 50% of ptns
    1. For IV, just replace
}}
What is the most important factor in determining potency of anaesthetic agents
Lipid solubility(oil:gas coefficient) where the more lipid soluble, the more potent
